questions.stem: Navicular syndrome in horses is BEST described as:

options.label: A
options.text: An acute infectious arthritis of the fetlock

options.label: B
options.text: A degenerative disease complex affecting structures within the navicular apparatus, usually bilaterally

options.label: C
options.text: A congenital hoof deformity present at birth

options.label: D
options.text: A transient soft tissue sprain of the limb

questions.explanation: Navicular syndrome is a degenerative disease complex of the navicular apparatus, often bilateral, rather than an acute infectious arthritis (A), congenital deformity (C), or simple sprain (D).

questions.stem: Which structures are part of the navicular apparatus that may be affected in navicular syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Navicular bone, navicular bursa, collateral sesamoid ligaments, distal impar ligament, and deep digital flexor tendon

options.label: B
options.text: Only the superficial digital flexor tendon

options.label: C
options.text: Only the laminae of the hoof wall

options.label: D
options.text: Only the suspensory ligament of the fetlock

questions.explanation: The navicular apparatus includes the navicular bone, navicular bursa, collateral sesamoid ligaments, distal impar ligament, and deep digital flexor tendon. The other options (B–D) list only isolated structures.

questions.stem: Which hoof conformation is MOST commonly associated with navicular syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Wide, flat feet with large frogs

options.label: B
options.text: Narrow, upright feet with contracted heels and small, narrow frogs

options.label: C
options.text: Club feet with excessively long heels

options.label: D
options.text: Laminitic feet with dropped soles

questions.explanation: Narrow, upright feet with contracted heels and small frogs predispose to navicular problems because of abnormal load distribution. Wide flat feet (A), club feet (C), and laminitic feet (D) have different pathologies.

questions.stem: How does body size relative to hoof size predispose horses to navicular syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Large horses with large hooves have no risk

options.label: B
options.text: Horses with small hooves and relatively large bodies concentrate high loads on small feet

options.label: C
options.text: Ponies with small bodies are most affected regardless of hoof size

options.label: D
options.text: Only miniature horses are at risk

questions.explanation: Horses with small hooves relative to body size concentrate high loads on a small area, increasing stress on the navicular apparatus. Large hooves (A) do not eliminate risk, and ponies/miniatures alone (C, D) do not account for the breed pattern.

questions.stem: Which management factors are considered predisposing for navicular syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Excellent farriery and balanced hooves

options.label: B
options.text: Poor distal limb or hoof conformation, hoof imbalance (long toes, low heels), poor hoof management, and undersized shoes

options.label: C
options.text: Lack of any work or exercise

options.label: D
options.text: Feeding high-fat diets

questions.explanation: Poor conformation, hoof imbalance (long toes, low heels), poor hoof care, and undersized shoes all contribute to excessive strain on navicular structures. Good farriery (A) is protective, while inactivity (C) and diet (D) are less direct risk factors.

questions.stem: In warmblood breeds, navicular syndrome may have which additional component?

options.label: A
options.text: Viral etiology

options.label: B
options.text: Genetic predisposition

options.label: C
options.text: Nutritional deficiency

options.label: D
options.text: Tick-borne origin

questions.explanation: In warmbloods, navicular syndrome may have a heritable component, suggesting a genetic predisposition. Viral (A), nutritional (C), or tick-borne (D) etiologies are not primary.

questions.stem: Typical clinical presentation of navicular syndrome includes:

options.label: A
options.text: Bilateral forelimb lameness, often worse in one limb, with shortened stride, shuffling gait, and stumbling

options.label: B
options.text: Acute unilateral hindlimb paralysis

options.label: C
options.text: Diffuse muscle atrophy without lameness

options.label: D
options.text: Respiratory distress and coughing

questions.explanation: Typical presentation is bilateral forelimb lameness (often asymmetrical), with a shortened stride, shuffling gait, and stumbling; owners may misinterpret this as shoulder lameness. Hindlimb paralysis (B) and purely muscular or respiratory signs (C, D) are atypical.

questions.stem: Where is pain most commonly elicited on hoof tester examination in navicular horses?

options.label: A
options.text: Toe region only

options.label: B
options.text: Heel or frog region

options.label: C
options.text: Sole of the hind feet only

options.label: D
options.text: Coronary band only

questions.explanation: Heel or frog pain on hoof tester exam is common in navicular horses, reflecting involvement of the caudal foot. Toe-only (A), hind sole (C), or coronary band (D) pain alone suggests other conditions.

questions.stem: Which diagnostic test often relieves navicular pain and reveals lameness in the opposite limb?

options.label: A
options.text: Abaxial sesamoid nerve block

options.label: B
options.text: Palmar digital nerve block

options.label: C
options.text: Peroneal nerve block

options.label: D
options.text: Infraorbital nerve block

questions.explanation: Palmar digital nerve block desensitizes the heel region and often relieves navicular pain, unmasking lameness in the opposite foot. Abaxial sesamoid, peroneal, and infraorbital blocks (A, C, D) target different areas.

questions.stem: Radiographic findings supportive of navicular syndrome may include:

options.label: A
options.text: Only normal navicular bone shape

options.label: B
options.text: Cyst-like lesions, enlarged vascular channels, medullary sclerosis, enthesiophytes, bone fragments, or flexor cortex erosions

options.label: C
options.text: Diffuse osteomyelitis of the cannon bone

options.label: D
options.text: Only laminar separation

questions.explanation: Radiographic changes may include cyst-like lesions, enlarged vascular channels, medullary sclerosis, enthesiophytes, bone fragments, and flexor cortex erosions. Normal bones (A), cannon osteomyelitis (C), or laminar separation (D) do not define navicular disease.

questions.stem: Which advanced imaging modality provides the most detailed evaluation of all podotrochlear structures?

options.label: A
options.text: Radiography alone

options.label: B
options.text: MRI

options.label: C
options.text: CT, which is more detailed than MRI

options.label: D
options.text: Scintigraphy only

questions.explanation: MRI offers the most detailed evaluation of all podotrochlear structures (bone, tendons, ligaments, bursa); CT is useful but less comprehensive. Radiographs (A) and scintigraphy (D) provide complementary but less detailed information.

questions.stem: Which conservative (medical) management strategies are commonly used initially for navicular syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate neurectomy without imaging

options.label: B
options.text: Trimming and shoeing changes, rest, and systemic NSAIDs such as phenylbutazone or firocoxib

options.label: C
options.text: High-dose corticosteroid injections in all joints

options.label: D
options.text: Stall rest only with no hoof changes

questions.explanation: Initial conservative management includes trimming and shoeing changes, rest, and systemic NSAIDs (e.g., phenylbutazone, firocoxib). Immediate neurectomy (A), blanket corticosteroids (C), or stall rest without farriery (D) are not recommended first-line.

questions.stem: Which intrasynovial therapies can be used for navicular syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Intra-articular corticosteroids and biologics (e.g., into the DIP joint or navicular bursa)

options.label: B
options.text: Only intra-articular antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Intra-articular local anesthetic alone

options.label: D
options.text: Oral vitamins

questions.explanation: Intrasynovial therapies include corticosteroids and/or biologics injected into the DIP joint or navicular bursa to reduce inflammation and pain. Solely antibiotics (B), local anesthetic (C), or oral vitamins (D) are insufficient.

questions.stem: What is the role of bisphosphonates in navicular syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: They have no role

options.label: B
options.text: Systemic bisphosphonates (tiludronate or clodronate) can help modulate bone pain and remodeling

options.label: C
options.text: They are only used in foals with developmental disease

options.label: D
options.text: They cure the disease permanently with a single dose

questions.explanation: Bisphosphonates such as tiludronate or clodronate can help by modulating bone turnover and alleviating bone-related pain; they do not cure the disease with a single dose (D). They are not useless (A) nor restricted to foals (C).

questions.stem: Which regenerative or biologic therapies have been used in some navicular cases with soft tissue lesions?

options.label: A
options.text: Mesenchymal stem cells, autologous conditioned serum, and platelet-rich plasma

options.label: B
options.text: Only antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Only dewormers

options.label: D
options.text: Only antihistamines

questions.explanation: Mesenchymal stem cells, autologous conditioned serum, and platelet-rich plasma are used in some cases, especially where soft tissue lesions in the navicular region are documented. Antibiotics, dewormers, or antihistamines alone (B–D) are not regenerative therapies.

questions.stem: Indications for navicular bursoscopy include:

options.label: A
options.text: Mild lameness responding to NSAIDs

options.label: B
options.text: Debridement of dorsal DDFT tears or flexor cortex erosions and removal of adhesions in the proximal navicular bursa

options.label: C
options.text: Routine exam of all sound horses

options.label: D
options.text: Sole bruising without imaging changes

questions.explanation: Navicular bursoscopy is indicated to debride dorsal DDFT tears, address flexor cortex erosions, and remove adhesions in the navicular bursa when present. Routine use in sound horses (C) or sole bruising without imaging (D) is not appropriate.

questions.stem: Palmar digital neurectomy may be considered when:

options.label: A
options.text: Medical treatment has failed and there is no significant DDFT damage on MRI

options.label: B
options.text: At the first sign of mild heel pain

options.label: C
options.text: In foals less than 1 year old

options.label: D
options.text: To diagnose the cause of lameness

questions.explanation: Palmar digital neurectomy is considered when medical and farriery management fail and MRI shows no significant DDFT damage, to avoid catastrophic tendon rupture post-desensitization. It is not first-line (B) and is inappropriate in foals (C) or as a diagnostic (D).

questions.stem: Which complications may occur after palmar digital neurectomy?

options.label: A
options.text: None; it is always curative

options.label: B
options.text: Painful neuroma formation, recurrence of lameness due to nerve regrowth, and undetected foot infection due to loss of sensation

options.label: C
options.text: Only laminitis

options.label: D
options.text: Only colic

questions.explanation: Complications include painful neuroma formation, recurrence of lameness due to nerve regrowth, and risk of undetected foot injury or infection due to loss of sensation. It is not always curative (A), and laminitis or colic alone (C, D) are not the principal concerns.

questions.stem: What owner care is especially important after neurectomy?

options.label: A
options.text: No special care is needed

options.label: B
options.text: Regular foot monitoring and, often, full pad shoeing to protect the desensitized foot

options.label: C
options.text: Stopping farriery visits

options.label: D
options.text: Increased high-speed exercise

questions.explanation: Owners must monitor feet carefully and often use full pad shoeing to protect the desensitized hoof and prevent trauma. Neglecting farriery (C) or increasing intense exercise (D) is unsafe.

questions.stem: Which overall statement about prognosis for navicular syndrome is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an acute disease that resolves completely with short-term treatment

options.label: B
options.text: It is a progressive degenerative condition; many horses improve with treatment but may deteriorate over time, and lifelong management is often needed

options.label: C
options.text: It never causes lameness

options.label: D
options.text: It always leads to euthanasia within one year

questions.explanation: Navicular syndrome is progressive and degenerative; while many horses improve with treatment, some deteriorate over time and require lifelong management. It is not an acute self-limiting problem (A), not always subclinical (C), and does not invariably cause rapid euthanasia (D).
